data: Five score years ago, a distinguished American, in whose symbolic shade we stand today, endorsed the Proclamation of Emancipation. This momentous edict arrived as a great shining hope to millions of African-American slaves who had been scorched in the fires of withering injustice. It arrived as a jubilant dawn to conclude the lengthy night of captivity.

But a century later, the Negro still remains unfree. One hundred years later, the existence of the Negro is still tragically impaired by the shackles of segregation and the fetters of discrimination. One hundred years later, the Negro dwells on a solitary island of poverty amidst an immense sea of material prosperity. One hundred years later, the Negro is still trapped in the corners of American society and finds himself an outcast in his own land.

Five score years in the past, an eminent American, under whose emblematic shade we stand today, signed the Proclamation of Emancipation. This monumental decree arrived as a remarkable beacon of hope to millions of Negro slaves who had been branded in the fires of withering injustice. It arrived as a jubilant daybreak to conclude the prolonged night of captivity.

However, one hundred years later, the Negro still remains unbound. One century later, the life of the Negro is still sorrowfully debilitated by the restraints of segregation and the chains of prejudice. One century later, the Negro resides on a solitary island of poverty amidst a vast ocean of material prosperity. One century later, the Negro is still languishing in the margins of American society and finds himself an exile in his own land.

Five score years ago, a great American, in whose symbolic shadow we stand today, enacted the Emancipation Proclamation. This monumental declaration came as a tremendous beacon light of optimism to millions of African-American slaves who had been seared in the fires of withering injustice. It came as a blissful daybreak to end the protracted night of captivity.

But one hundred years later, the Negro still remains unshackled. One hundred years later, the life of the black is still sorrowfully hindered by the shackles of segregation and the fetters of discrimination. One hundred years later, the Negro resides on a desolate island of poverty amidst an extensive ocean of material prosperity. One hundred years later, the Negro is still trapped in the fringes of American society and finds himself an outcast in his land.

Five score years ago, an illustrious American, in whose symbolic shade we stand today, affixed his signature to the Emancipation Proclamation. This momentous decree arrived as a shining beacon of hope to millions of Negro slaves who had been seared in the flames of withering injustice. It arrived as a joyful daybreak to bring an end to the long night of captivity.

But one hundred years later, the Negro still remains unfree. One hundred years later, the life of the Negro is still tragically hindered by the shackles of segregation and the chains of discrimination. One hundred years later, the Negro resides on a solitary island of impoverishment amidst a vast sea of material prosperity. One hundred years later, the Negro is still languishing in the margins of American society and finds himself an exile in his own land.

Five score years ago, a prominent American, in whose emblematic shadow we stand today, endorsed the Emancipation Proclamation. This significant decree arrived as a great beacon of hope to millions of African-American slaves who had been burned in the fires of withering injustice. It arrived as a joyous dawn to bring an end to the lengthy night of captivity.

However, one hundred years later, the Negro still remains unfettered. One century later, the existence of the Negro is still sadly crippled by the restraints of segregation and the bonds of discrimination. One century later, the Negro resides on a solitary island of impoverishment amidst an expansive ocean of material prosperity. One century later, the Negro is still trapped in the corners of American society and finds himself an outcast in his own land.

This monumental edict arrived as a great shining ray of hope to millions of Negro slaves who had been scorched in the flames of withering injustice. It arrived as a joyous daybreak to conclude the prolonged night of captivity.

But a century later, the Negro still remains unliberated. One hundred years later, the life of the Negro is still tragically impaired by the restraints of segregation and the chains of discrimination. One hundred years later, the Negro dwells on a solitary island of poverty amidst a vast sea of material prosperity. One hundred years later, the Negro is still trapped in the peripheries of American society and finds himself an exile in his own land.

It arrived as a blissful dawn to conclude the protracted night of captivity.

But one hundred years later, the Negro still remains unbound. One hundred years later, the life of the Negro is still sorrowfully hindered by the handcuffs of segregation and the fetters of prejudice. One hundred years later, the Negro is still languishing in the margins of American society and finds himself an outcast in his own land.
